So -- big surprise! -- Just Eat customers aren't hugely impressed with the quality of the product they buy from Just Eat, which the company has no control over whatsoever.

11:15 am

All of which is all kinda like blaming Yellow Pages for having listings for cowboy builders.

hehehehe

11:15 am
BE

Want to read the cover page? Because here it is.

BE

Our Evidence Lab survey of 2,000 consumers in the UK and France suggests that, while Just Eat is the leading takeaway aggregator in both countries, it does not meet our respondents' expectations for two of the top three factors they deem most important when ordering takeaway food: "taste of food" and "value for money". We believe emerging alternative platforms add more value and that their adverse impact on Just Eat's future market share gains is currently being underestimated by market participants.

BE

Just Eat estimates takeaway food is a c£60bn market globally, of which perhaps 30-40% is currently ordered online. As the online share grows, companies like Just Eat stand to benefit. However, we believe three-sided marketplaces that include a delivery element – like Deliveroo and UberEATS – represent more compelling solutions for both diners and restaurants, since they have greater control over quality and delivery times, and offer online access to restaurants that do not have delivery capabilities.

11:16 am
BE

In 2014, 5% of takeaway orders (by value) were made on Just Eat's platform in the markets in which it was present. Its target (with no specified deadline) is 39%. We believe the market is pricing in a 19% share by 2030, equivalent to Just Eat's market share in its core market, the UK. Similarly, we believe the market is assuming EBITDA margins of greater than 40% for the group by 2030, in line with the UK's strong profit margin today. We feel that increased competition will cause investors to scale back expectations for growth generated per marketing dollar spent. We model a 16% market share in 2030 and a 33% group EBITDA margin.

BE

We value Just Eat using a DCF model, assuming an 8.5% WACC and 2% terminal growth rate. We caution that given the immaturity of the business and the industry, there is a wide scope of possible outcomes for Just Eat. Thus, our upside-downside range is wide, at 140-660p.

BE

The gist as you advance through the note is that Just Eat will need to throw money at advertising, because what else can it do?

11:17 am
BE

And it probably won't be able to increase the rake as much as management has guided, because obviously. It's Yellow Pages for chicken shops.

PM

Yellow Pages for chicken shops.

PM

This is brutal Bryce

So anyway, Domino's is a much better business.

Unfortunately, it's already quite expensive.

11:18 am
Domino's Pizza Group PLC (DOM:LSE): Last: 977.08, down 7.42 (-0.75%), High: 1,008, Low: 971.50, Volume: 72.64k
BE

Here's that cover page.

BE

Our Evidence Lab survey of more than 1,000 respondents in the UK
gives us confidence that the impact of third-party operators such as Just Eat should be
limited in the long term, and that Domino's can continue to benefit from the increasing
penetration of online and mobile in the UK takeaway market. We forecast a 9.3%
revenue CAGR in 2015-19, and an 11.0% earnings CAGR. We initiate coverage with a
Neutral rating on valuation grounds, with a price target of 975p.

11:18 am
BE

Our survey analysing consumer food delivery habits showed that taste of food and
delivery speed were among the top four factors most valued by consumers –neither of
which can be controlled by third-party operators. And since 70% of respondents prefer
to order directly from restaurants rather than aggregators and Domino's has higher
brand awareness – 82% of respondents are aware of Domino's versus just 71% for
Just Eat – Domino’s is in a much stronger position than its aggregator competitors.

BE

Analysis of the remaining market potential in the UK shows there is still significant
upside to current store numbers; however, we believe the rate of roll-out will be
constrained by the reliance on franchisees' willingness to expand. In addition, we think
the long-term growth potential of Domino's has been limited by the JV of the German
business. Whilst this provides a short-term fix to what has been a problematic region,
we think Domino's has lost a significant long-term growth opportunity.

PM

Actually we should also share Neil Campling cos he's been well ahead of the game on this

11:20 am
BE

Of course.

PM

Just Eat (Short). Another bulge bracket sell rating on Just Eat today. In contrast to the other report last week which focused on changing supply dynamics (increased competition) this focuses on the demand side of the platform. We have issues on both sides of the platform. Supply in 2016 will see rising competition from well funded rivals, ranging from Deliveroo who has funding from JE's early VC backers (and Facebook's) to new high profile entrants Uber and Amazon in our view. And on demand there is no switching costs for customers, a lack of brand loyalty and incentives for restaurants to push direct ordering.

The big difference in our view is in our belief their operating leverage expectations will not transpire. Even the bulge bracket bears have rising commission rates and rising EBITDA margins. We suspect both will come under significant pressure as market dynamics unfold, just as has become apparent in the US market. For Just Eat the street expects 33% sales growth but a substantial 59% EBITDA growth in 2016. In 2017 sales slow to 24% growth but EBITDA will grow at almost double the rate 42%. But will it? If Uber enters the UK market in 2016, as we expect, this new competitor would bring a similar unowned driver network with three key advantages over Just Eat: scale, brand awareness and logistical technology expertise. Just Eat’s marketing budget is already high at ~25% of sales and this is only likely to increase in a defensive strategy to maintain growth/share. As such, the implied operational leverage is unlikely. We remain short JE/ LN

11:24 am
Premier Oil PLC (PMO:LSE): Last: 40.00, up 21 (+110.53%), High: 45.00, Low: 32.00, Volume: 23.48m
BE

Which is mostly a reflection of its previous state of stress, rather than a certainty that the tax-dodging deal will work out.

BE

Basically, Premier had been priced to breach covenants. Now it won't, for a bit.

11:26 am
BE

Nomura's probably the most positive of the sellside.

BE

We outline three reasons to turn buyers: 1) our analysis of the data for the
pending EON deal suggests it is value accretive and positive to PMO's debt
covenants; 2) the re-negotiation of partner capex carry in Falklands reduces
the future debt; and 3) the above two factors increase the duration and value
of the call option that PMO shares offer investors to higher oil prices. The
downside case is an equity valuation that is negligible if the forward curve
materialises, which should be well known. However, we also see an option
with a payoff of greater than 5x in the event of higher prices (NMRe NAV of c200p/sh
assuming USD 70/bbl and 45p/therm). With increasing capacity to survive
current prices for at least 12 months, we think the risk-reward from a broader
portfolio basis (either as a hedge to UW Energy position or as an outright bull
on oil prices), is worth taking. Short-term, our base case is the UKLA lifts the
existing trading suspension (either when PMO/EON can either produce the
relevant financial information or the authority decides this transaction is not a
reverse takeover) and we anticipate the shares should trade materially higher,
beyond pre-suspension levels of 40p (last close price of 19p/sh).

BE

We view the USD 120m E.On UK acquisition as positive as: 1) the
predominately gas assets reduces the stock’s NPV sensitivity (using a 10%
discount rate) to weaker oil prices; 2) the assets increase our risked NAV by
c35p/share on the forward curve, including c25p from higher utilisation of
historic UK tax losses; and 3) it increases the company’s 2016 covenant
headroom by cUSD 500m.

11:27 am
BE

A USD 30-40/bbl outlook through 2016/17 leaves debt covenants precariously
poised with ND/EBITDAX above 6x (covenant is currently 4.75x). Whilst we
believe lending banks will be flexible during 2016, management remains under
pressure to deliver on cost reduction and portfolio restructuring into 2017.

PM

bit scary eh

BE

The key to this deal is that Premier's able to offset profit against its $3.5bn of historical UK tax losses.

11:28 am
BE

One can argue about the quality of the assets bought. We have previously, in fact.

PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

I think Premier's on the hook for $450m of decommissioning liabilities here. Whether that figure goes up in future, I don't know. But I'd not be surprised.

11:30 am
BE

Caz is a bit cautious.

BE

As per our recent initiation, we would be hesitant
to bet against Premier’s ability to adapt to the macro environment. This acquisition
surprises given the use of cash, which likely helped Premier achieve an attractive
price (although E.ON are also taking greater than €150m cash out of the UK operating
company, and are passing an E.ON estimated €450m of decommissioning liabilities
to Premier – beginning in 2019/2020 (Ravenspurn North).

BE

The addition of the E.ON assets, less the $135m consideration and the various model
updates causes our NAV to increase 6p (9%) to 71p. We leave our price target
unchanged at 60p, which represents a slight increase to the discount to NAV, driven
by the risk that Premier will need to seek an adjustment to covenants despite the
improvement in its financial position post the E.ON acquisition

11:31 am
BE

In terms of the covenants ........

BE

While we do not have full details on
the financial statements. Given production, hedging and opex, guidance on
an annualized basis the transaction could add to $80-90m EBITDA. If we
assume deal completion in April, the 8 months production would imply
$53-60m EBITDA representing 11-12% of our forecast FY16 EBITDA. If
Brent averages $50/bbl per our forecast then we would expect PMO to
avoid any covenant breach (JPMe ND/EBITDAX 4.25x), or to put another
way we see PMO, post transaction, requiring an oil price of $46/bbl to avoid
the need for a covenant waiver versus a prior estimate of $53/bbl in 2016.

BE

Incidentally, I've not gone into the detail of why Premier was allowed to come off suspension while it's still negotiating a reverse takeover that's not been approved by shareholders yet.

PM

The Group has continued its strong bidding success since the start of the year, increasing our number of framework contracts by 22%, from 181 to 221. Integration is well advanced on the five acquisitions made in 2015 and all are performing in line with our expectations.

We are however operating against a backdrop of active cost reductions taking place within client organisations, resulting in part from a requirement for social landlords to reduce rents by 1% p.a. for the next four years. In certain cases, client expenditure commitments are being held back until budgets are confirmed in April 2016. As such, despite our success in securing positions on key frameworks, including resecuring Eastern Procurement, the expected level of tenders from these frameworks has not materialised at the rate previously expected. This has led to a slower than expected first quarter performance in Regeneration and as a consequence, a lowering of our financial expectations for the division in the current financial year.

PM

In light of the above headwinds the Group now expects the financial outturn for the current year to fall short of its previous expectations and to see a reduction on last year's profit level.

BE

Client budget hesitancy leads to material EPS downgrade
Lakehouse has brought forward its AGM statement. Client
procurement delays and reduced discretionary spending has led
to a warning that profits in Regeneration and Energy Services
will be materially below expectations. Whilst recent acquisitions
and the other divisions are in line, we have reduced our Sep
2016 EPS by 20%. Whilst a disappointing turn of events
(especially given the increasing number of frameworks secured),
this may prove to be partly an issue of timing. The inevitable
share price reaction this morning is likely to create a buying
opportunity.

forecast increases from £8.7m to £17m but remains well within total facilities of
£45m. Our FY 2016 dividend reduces to 3.5p from 4.2p.

Instead, here's SocGen on the numbers.

11:45 am
BE

BT Q3 revenue rose an underlying 4.7% to £4,594m or 2.5% ahead of
consensus. EBITDA rose 3% to £1,613m or 1.4% ahead; and adjusted EPS reached 9p or 9% ahead partly due to interest income on unpaid taxes. Cash flow was 7.5% ahead of SGe at £904m (EBITDA and working capital), with net debt of £5,021m slightly lower too. Within the divisions, the revenue beat was driven by Global Services with underlying revenue up 2% (-3% H1), as the UK grew 2% (-10% H1) helped by equipment revenue. In EBITDA terms, GS was 3% ahead thanks to a mild 1% rise in operating costs, while at Consumer EBITDA grew 8% (5% ahead) due to top line growth of 11% (calls and lines +5% and broadband +23% versus 1% and 17% respectively last quarter) and slower growth in non-rights cost at 3% (6% Q2). Q3 KPIs were particularly strong, with retail broadband adds of 130k (vs 81k in Q2 16 and 119k in Q3 15), fibre +250k (+212k, +209k), TV +97k (+106k in Q2 for UEFA launch, +45k Q3 15) and consumer voice lines up versus previous declines.

BE

Potential impact on SG & market forecast We expect a low single digit rise in consensus
EPS post results due to stronger the EBITDA and KPIs. BT tweaks revenue guidance to
1-2% growth for the year from the previous ‘growth’, otherwise guidance is unchanged.
From here the main drivers remain the EE acquisition, which we expect to boost growth
from 3% to 6-8% CAGR for EPS, DPS and CFPS over the next five years, and the outlook
for regulation. BT also announced changes in its structure today to incorporate EE but full
guidance will only come in May, nothing was added on the regulatory outlook.

BE

(@cheeckychappy: "colourful" means I don't want to spend the afternoon talking to the lawyer.)

11:46 am
BE

Our DCF-based SOTP reaches 550p (Openreach 29% EV, Mobile 28%, Consumer 18%). Risks to rec., rating and TP: EE synergies miss (SGe £4bn cost, £3-4bn revenue); mobile ARPU trends (each +/- 1pp pa = 10p per share); regulations (e.g., GEA/fibre pricing regulation: +-1pp =+-15p on valuation. Openreach structural split (not our assumption) could negatively impact sentiment and/or valuation.

BE

And Morgan Stanley ......

BE

we caution against extrapolating these trends into Q4:

11:47 am
BE

1. This quarter benefited from a “double” price increase. That is, there
was a price increase in December 2014, but in 2015, the price increase
came in September.
2. Openreach is coming up against tougher comps. In Q4 last year,
Openreach added 455k fibre net adds, which was a company record
before this quarter at 494k. This winter’s stormy weather (leading to
more fault repairs) is also likely to be a drag.
3. BT wholesale last year benefited from c£30mn settlement of ladder
price arrangements.

11:52 am
BE

Deal's gone from "nearly dead" to "on the cusp of agreement", basically inside 24 hours.

BE

http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3yuXCiVjm

BE

Because Schroders and Toscafund have engaged the mind erasers with regards to all that stuff a few weeks ago about them not selling for less than 200p.

11:53 am
BE

Now, it's 165p.

BE

J Sainsbury has been told that it must increase its takeover offer for Home Retail Group to at least 160p per share if it hopes to salvage a deal to buy the owner of catalogue retailer Argos.
The guidance came after the British grocer met late last week with the two largest shareholders in Home Retail —- Schroders and Toscafund — which together own nearly a third of the company — people close to the matter said. The investors have indicated that an offer at that level, or preferably closer to 165p, would be enough for them to support a bid and pressure Home Retail’s board to accept a deal.

BE

So does it get done? Dunno.

11:55 am
BE

Neither does Clive Black, but he sets out the unknowns nicely.

BE

Pressure points are considerable as Sainsbury's has said that it will display financial discipline through this process. Such a stand may be particularly relevant to the leading shareholder, the QIA (Qatar Investment Authority), where there has been the remarkable incidence of Sainsbury's having to clarify that purported newspaper stories of the investor's interest, or otherwise, are a load of tosh. At the same time there may be some Home Retail shareholders seeking to goad its management to remain firm for as much 200p, in our opinion; more than double the pre-Christmas share price.

BE

Without going into an extended debate on the merits of this bid, as this stage of the process will come to a head soon, we remain torn on the matter. Those with a deeper knowledge of Argos than us point out the structural challenges faced by the business and, as such, Sainsbury's may be buying problems where solutions do not appear to be a matter of lifting a package from a shelf.

In‎deed, we remain intrigued and concerned to see if the real estate prize, highlighted in the market release to date, can be achieved in a profitable manner for Sainsbury's. What we mean by this is that we can we can certainly foresee the closure of high street Argos stores. Less clear is whether or not high street Argos customers will simply get into their cars and drive to a Sainsbury's supermarket for the Argos proposition. Such an imponderable item is central to the revenue synergies that must be factored into this deal's mathematics.

11:56 am
BE

Risk of non-migration
In this respect, the customer overlap between Argos and Sainsbury's, whilst considerable for sure, is far from symmetrical and so there is a risk that the business ‎from those closed Argos high street stores may go elsewhere and those folk not already shopping at Sainsbury's for their groceries will stay with their existing outlets, many of which are price-stronger than Sainsbury's.

The last mile prize
At the same time, Messrs. Coupe & Rogers are folk we respect. As such their case has not been properly presented from a financial perspective‎, and this surely needs to be undertaken before a sober appraisal of their approach can be properly considered. In this respect, in addition to not over-paying there is the potential leverage of Argos' eCommerce, click & collect and last mile capabilities that needs to be considered.

Questions, questions...
So, not long to wait now to see if a) a deal can be agreed between both parties, b) if so, whether both sets of shareholders will approve it c) will the Competition & Markets Authority throw its oar in, d) will there be counter-bids for Home Retail and e) would Sainsbury go hostile. Interesting times.

BE

Nonse of which is particularly tradable, so I suggest you don't.
